    "title": "Can Unconditional Cash Transfers Lead to Sustainable Poverty Reduction? Evidence from two government-led programmes in Zambia",
    "matches_expected_title": "YES"
  },

    "program_name": "Child Grant Programme (CGP) and Multiple Category Targeted Programme (MCP)",
    "country": "Zambia",
    "region": "Rural districts",
    "target_population": "Ultra-poor households, with CGP targeting households with a child under age three and MCP targeting vulnerable households (female or elderly head keeping orphans, or a household with a disabled member)"
  },

    "component_a_cash_support": {
      "component_a_present": true,
      "cash_support_type": "unconditional cash transfer",
      "cash_amount": "USD 12 per month (USD 24 PPP)",
      "cash_frequency": "bimonthly",
      "is_loan_or_credit": "NO",
      "cash_evidence_citation": "Each programme was accompanied by a randomized control trial (RCT) with one baseline and several longitudinal post-intervention follow-ups starting at 24-months. Both models entailed a flat unconditional cash transfer of approximately USD12 (USD24 PPP) per month paid every two months."
    },
    "component_b_assets": {
      "component_b_present": false,
      "assets_provided": [],
      "direct_provision": "NO",
      "assets_evidence_citation": "No mention of direct asset transfers found in the paper. The discussion mentions increased livestock holdings and agricultural tools, but these were purchased by households using cash transfers."
    }
  },

    "outcomes_measured": [
      "consumption/expenditure",
      "food security/nutrition",
      "children's schooling",
      "material well-being",
      "economic capacity",
      "asset accumulation",
      "non-farm business activity",
      "agricultural production"
    ],
    "outcomes_evidence_citation": "A relatively simple flat cash transfer, unconditional and paid bimonthly, has wide-ranging effects on ultra-poor households in rural Zambia, significantly raising consumption, food security and children's schooling and material well-being, while at the same time strengthening economic capacity and assets. [...] For the CGP this is through non-farm business activity and the increased revenue generated from these businesses. The CGP also has a significant impact on the value of sales of agricultural products. For the MCP, this is through the value of crop production, and given the large increment in livestock holdings, possibly through the sale of livestock-derived products such as eggs."
    ,
    "study_design": "Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)",
    "design_evidence_citation": "Each programme was accompanied by a randomized control trial (RCT) with one baseline and several longitudinal post-intervention follow-ups starting at 24-months.",

    "publication_year": 2016,
    "study_conducted_year": "2010-2015",

[...] Results of this exercise are shown in Table 9, and range from 1.23 in the CGP at 36-months to 2.08 in the MCP at 36 months. Using the pooled estimates and averaging across both programmes gives a multiplier of 1.59.",
    "cost_evidence_citation": "The annual amount transferred to a household is USD144 (or USD288 PPP). [...] Results of this exercise are shown in Table 9, and range from 1.23 in the CGP at 36-months to 2.08 in the MCP at 36 months. Using the pooled estimates and averaging across both programmes gives a multiplier of 1.59."
  },
  "evidence_citations": {
    "program_name_citation": "The Child Grant Programme (CGP) targeted all households with a child under age three in three poor rural districts, while the Multiple Category Targeted Programme (MCP) targeted vulnerable households, those with a female or elderly head keeping orphans, or a household with a disabled member, in two rural districts.",
    "country_citation": "In 2010, the Zambian government began testing two different cash transfer models to inform future scale-up decisions.",
    "target_population_citation": "The Child Grant Programme (CGP) targeted all households with a child under age three in three poor rural districts, while the Multiple Category Targeted Programme (MCP) targeted vulnerable households, those with a female or elderly head keeping orphans, or a household with a disabled member, in two rural districts."
